prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N2D+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim at imaging the N2D+(4-3)line toward the central 1000 AU of the pre-stellar core L1544, to trace the seeds of star formation, recently discovered with AlMA Cycle 2. Simultaneously, we will attempt to detect the ground state transition of ND3 as well as SO and 13CH3OH, in case one of the seeds has already warmed up in its way to star formation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We go to the high resolution, in case the lines are brighter (see above), as the lines are expected to be narrow. In case we need more sensitivity (as in the conservative case predicted by our model), we will degrade the spectral resolution to 0.1 km/s, which will still allow us to have at least three channels within a full width at half maximum of the line and well measure centroid velocities and kinematics within the central 1000 AU of this pre-stellar core.
One baseband has been tuned to one SO and one 13CH3OH lines to check for possible internal heating within the seeds, in case of gravitational compression.

We expect the emission to be brighter and more compact than the 2 arcsec requested in the sensitivity calculator, considering that our model is smooth and it does not include sub-structure (for simplicity). Therefore, a 0.5 arcsec resolution is requested to allow us to resolve the seeds in the continuum, as well as in line emission in the more optimistic scenario of compact and bright substructure. However, the sensitivity estimates are done in the more pessimistic scenario. The C36-2 configuraton allows us to cover both the scenarios simultaneously, while, at the same time, minimizing the shadowing for this Northern source. Because the largest scale is expected to be about 15 arceconds (based on modeling), we request ACA observations.
To study the dust evolition across the map, together with the 3mm continuum data, the 1mm continuum map will be smoothed to 1 arcsec.

The requested rms is based on simulated observations of N2D+(4-3). These have been obtained using a detailed chemical model, inclusive of deuterium and spin-state chemistry (Sipila et al. 2015), applied to the well-known physical structure of L1544 (Keto & Caselli 2010) and a Monte Carlo non-LTE radiative transfer code. This model well reproduces the recent ALMA Cycle 2 observations of the N2D+(3-2) line toward the center of L1544 (see Figure 2 in the proposal). We request a S/N of 5 at the peak of the emission, i.e. toward one of the fragments (or seeds) recently discovered, where we expect a line brightness of 130 mK (see Figure 4 in the proposal). Because of the narrow lines (about 0.3 km/s), we need spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s and a beam size of 2 arcsec.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Deuterated ammonia
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Ammonia and deuterated ammonia are known to be good tracers of pre-stellar cores and here we focus on the ground state transition of NH2D and NHD2, whose critical densities are above 1e7 cm-3. We expect that they will also be present toward the core center and trace the seeds. Our model includes deuterium and spin state chemistry, so we give accurate predictions of their abundances. Their detection can then test our models and give us information about other parameters on which our model depend, such as the cosmic-ray ionisation rate. Their centrorid velocities will be compared to those of N2D+(4-3), which is predicted to trace similar regions, and we will investigate the possible presence of velocity shifts, as expected in case of magnetised molecular clouds.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We go to the high resolution, in case the lines are brighter (see above), as the lines are expected to be narrow and display some structure due to possible freeze-out. In case we need more sensitivity (as in the conservative case predicted by our model), we will degrade the spectral resolution to 0.2 km/s, which will still allow us to resolve the broad structure produced by the hyperfine splitting (see Figure 4 in the proposal) and it will allow us to have enough channels to measure the centroid velocities accurately, as well as the kinematics within the central 1000 AU of this pre-stellar core.
One baseband is dedicated to doubly deuterated ammonia, which is not predicted to be detectable, but in case of detection these lines could provide a strong constrain to our chemical model which includes deuterium and spin state chemistry.

We expect the emission to be brighter and more compact than the 2 arcsec requested in the sensitivity calculator, considering that our model is smooth and it does not include sub-structure (for simplicity). Therefore, a 0.5 arcsec resolution is requested to allow us to resolve the seeds in the continuum, as well as in the line emission in the more optimistic scenario of compact and brigth substructure. However, the sensitivity estimates are done in the more pessimistic scenario. The C36-2 configuration allows us to cover both the scenarios simultaneously, while, at the same time, minimizing the shadowing for this Northern source. Because the largest scale is expected to be about 15 arcsec (based on modeling), we request ACA observations.
To study the dust evolition across the map, together with the 3mm continuum data, the 1mm continuum map will be smoothed to 1 arcsec.

The requested rms is based on simulated observations of the ground state ortho-NH2D(1_01-0_00) line. These have been obtained using a detailed chemical model, inclusive of deuterium and spin-state chemistry (Sipila et al. 2015), applied to the well-known physical structure of L1544 (Keto & Caselli 2010) and a Monte Carlo non-LTE radiative transfer code. This model well reproduces the recent ALMA Cycle 2 observations of the N2D+(3-2) line toward the center of L1544 (see Figure 2 in the proposal). We request a S/N of 5 at the peak of the emission, i.e. toward one of the fragments (or seeds) recently discovered, where we expect a line brightness of 150 mK (see Figure 4 in the proposal) within 2 arcsec beam. For this particular transition we can smooth down to 0.2 km/s to increase sensitivity (because of the presence of several separated hyperfine components), but the observations will still be carried out with higher spectral resolution, in case the line will result stronger than expected (as our model is spherically symmetric and it does not include sub-structure).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ortho-H2D+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: ortho-H2D+ at 372 GHz is a great tracer of highly CO-depleted gas, so its detection in the direction of the seeds of star formation will give us clues on the chemical composition and evolution. ortho-H2D+ has been recently detected toward a pre-stellar core in an active star forming region using ALMA, so we expect to detect this line and help us to characterise the seeds. Comparison with the emission from the other selected lines will also give us information on the chemical time scale of the seeds and the amount of molecular freeze out at such extreme densities for cold material. We will also attempt to detect the SCO+(5-4) line, which is predicted to show a double peak profile, because of the almost complete CO-depletion toward the model core center.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We go to the high resolution, in case the lines are brighter (see above), as the lines are expected to be narrow and display some structure due to possible self-absorption (considering that the critical density of this transition is only 1e5 cm-3). In case we need more sensitivity (as in the conservative case predicted by our model) we will degrade the spectral resolution to 0.1 km/s, which will allow us to resolve the line and have enough channels to measure accurately the centroid velocity as well the kinematics within the central 1000 AU of this pre-stellar core.
One extra baseband will be centered on the DCO+(5-4) line, which is expected to be bright and display double peak structure because of the central depletion.

We expect the emission to be brighter and more compact than the 2 arcsec requested in the sensitivity calculator, considering that our model is smooth and it does not include sub-structure (for simplicity). Therefore, a 0.5 arcsec resolution is requested to allow us to resolve the seeds in the continuum, as well as in the line emission in the more optimistic scenario of compact an bright substructure. However, the sensitivity estimates are done in the more pessimistic scenario. The C36-2 configuration allows us to cover both the scenarios simultaneously, while, at the same time, minimizing the shadowing for this Northern source. Because the largest scale is expected to be about 15 arcsec (based on modeling), we request ACA.
To study the dust evolition across the map, together with the 3mm continuum data, the 1mm continuum map will be smoothed to 1 arcsec.

The requested rms is based on simulated observations of the ground state ortho-H2D+(1_10 - 1_11) line. These have been obtained using a detailed chemical model, inclusive of deuterium and spin-state chemistry (Sipila et al. 2015) and a Monte Carlo non-LTE radiative transfer code. This model well reproduces the recent ALMA Cycle 2 observations of the N2D+(3-2) line toward the center of L1544 (see Figure 2 in the proposal). We request a S/N of 5 at the peak of the emission, i.e. toward one of the fragments (or seeds) recently discovered, where we expect a line brightness of 1.1 K (see Figure 4 in the proposal) within 2 arcsec beam. As this is a single line (i.e. no hyprfine structure), we request the highest spectral resolution and we can smooth down to 0.1 km/s at most to make sure we well resolve the profile and measure the centroid velocity and width. In case of presence of completely depleted zones (predicted by Walmsley et al. 2004), the line is expected to be brighter, in which case the highest resolution will be used.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3mm continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is dedicated to the 3mm continuum, which, in combination with the 1mm continuum will give us information on possible dust evolution, allowing us to estimate the dust spectral index and opacity (assuming the dust and gas temperature derived from previous observations and modeling). Results from this science goal will test current models of dust grain coagulation in dense and slowly evolving molecular clouds.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is dedicated to the continuum to maximise the sensitivity. We used the suggested spectral configuration in the OT.

The angular resolution of 1 arcsec (obtained with configuration C36-3) is requested to allow comparison with the 1mm dust continuum maps at the size scales of the seeds of star formation (about 200 AU). This configuration choice will also allow us to avoid shadowing and best match the combination with ACA data, needed as the emission is expected to be exteded.

The requested rms allows us to compare with the sensitivity obtained with the combined 1mm dust continuum observations in the previous science goals and thus it allows us to constrain the spectral index, to find its value within the central 1000 AU and possibly map its variation. If the spectral index beta changes by a factor of 2 (i.e. dropping from the typical interstellar value of 2 - e.g. Schnee et al. 2010 - to values close to 1, in case of dust coagulation, as measured toward protoplanetary disks - e.g. Testi et al. 2014, PPVI), the ratio between the 1mm and 3mm fluxes change by a factor of 3. Therefore, we need to make sure that we can measure this ratio with an accuracy of at least 4 sigma, so that the individual fluxes need to be detected with an accuracy of at least 6 sigma. From our Cycle 2 data, the expected flux at 3mm (assuming beta = 2) within the central 1000 AU radius is 120 microJy/1 arcsec beam, so we request a sensitivity of 20microJy/1 arcsec beam to well detect the flux and possible variations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: With ALMA Cycle 2 we have recently discovered 200 AU-scale dense (~1e8 cm-3) structures within the central 1000 AU of a contracting pre-stellar core, L1544. These are the seeds of star formation, which can now be explored with ALMA Cycle 3. We plan to observe high density (>1e7 cm-3) tracers (in particular N2D+ and deuterated ammonia) to reveal the kinematics of the seeds and their links to the surrounding material, shedding light on seeds assembly and specific angular momentum evolution. The selected species, together with our comprehensive chemical model applied to the well-known physical structure of L1544, will allow us to measure the ionisation fraction in the seeds and test cosmic-ray propagation theories; comparison between the centroid velocities of ions and neutral species will reveal possible shifts expected in magnetised clouds; sensitive continuum maps at 3mm and 1mm will provide information on dust evolution. All this opens up the long-awaited opportunity to study the initial conditions in the process of stellar system formation up to unprecedented small scales and to test advanced dynamical/chemical models of evolving pre-stellar cores on the brink of star formation.
